case_vignette: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician with a 4-month history of recurrent crusty lesions on the dorsal surface of his hands. When he scrapes off the crusts, they reappear after a few days. The lesions are mildly pruritic and occasionally burn. He works as a landscaper. A photograph of his right hand is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

I haven't noticed any scarring or changes in skin color when they heal.

No, I haven't had any blistering or open sores with these lesions.

No, I do not have a history of similar skin issues or other chronic illnesses.

The information about my family's medical history regarding similar skin issues was not provided.

I'm not aware of any close family members having similar skin issues.

No, I am not taking any medications.
Final Diagnosis: Actinic Keratosis.
